newsitem.title: PERU: Peru sees sugar output up to 1 mln tonnes by 2000.
newsitem.headline: Peru sees sugar output up to 1 mln tonnes by 2000.

text.p: Peru expects to become a net sugar exporter by 2000 increasing output to 1 million tonnes a year from an estimated 650,000 tonnes in 1996, according to President Alberto Fujimori, the government daily El Peruano reported Tuesday.

Fujimori made his prediction late Monday at the opening of the annual meeting of the Latin American and Caribbean Sugar Exporters Group, known by its Spanish initials, Geplacea, being held this year in northern Peru at Trujillo.

Presidential adviser and former agricultural minister Absalon Vasquez said the president's goal was "perfectly feasible given that Peru has a great potential ... due to the government's willingness to reactivate the agricultural sector," El Peruano reported.
According to latest Agriculture Ministry figures Peru's sugar output for the first nine months this year fell 4.1 percent to 4.303 million tonnes, compared to the same period last year.
In the first nine months imports rose 28.4 percent to 235,538 tonnes, worth $79.4 million.
Geplacea, Mexico-based intergovernment organization made up of 23 countries, said its annual meeting will discuss restructuring its make-up given changes in international sugar markets.
